chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Any reform should keep elections administered by states but make presidential outcomes less dependent on a handful of battlegrounds and more aligned with how Americans vote overall. A practical middle ground is to require each state to award electors using a consistent, proportional method with a small “bonus” for the statewide winner, while binding electors and setting national minimums for ballot design, paper records, risk-limiting audits, and recount triggers. If the country later wants to move closer to a pure national tally, it should do so only after those integrity standards are in place so the rules stay simple, verifiable, and trusted across regions.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Keep the state-run structure of presidential elections, but make outcomes track voters more closely by ending winner-take-all and requiring proportional (or district-based) allocation of electors, with strong anti-gerrymandering safeguards where districts are used. Pair this with clear national baselines for ballots, paper-backed audits, binding electors to the certified vote, and automatic recount triggers so close results are transparent and trusted. If the country later wants to align even more directly with the national popular will, the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact can serve as a gradual, workable next step rather than an abrupt overhaul.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: A durable reform should make presidential elections feel fair no matter where you live—so fewer votes are “wasted” in safe states—while keeping states in charge of running elections with results people can verify. A workable middle path is to end winner-take-all and require proportional allocation of electors in every state, with electors bound to the vote, plus clear national baselines for ballot access, paper records, audits, and automatic recount triggers. If the country wants the winner to match the national vote more directly, the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact (and optional ranked-choice voting) can be phased in with the same transparency and safeguards.
